About
About
Jennifer Koster is a serial entrepreneur and systems integrator transforming the global built environment through innovation, precision, and execution. As Founder and CEO of WerkWell Holdings, she leads a vertically integrated group of companies advancing circular construction, sustainable real estate, and next-generation infrastructure. She is also Co-Founder of LivWell, where she is pioneering a wellness-driven development model rooted in regenerative systems and resilient design.

Jennifer brings a unique ability to synthesize complexity into action. Her core strength lies not just in visionary strategy, but in operationalizing that vision—aligning multi-disciplinary teams across design, engineering, finance, and community to deliver high-performance outcomes. Whether launching climate-aligned infrastructure or reimagining mixed-use communities, Jennifer leads with discipline, aligning stakeholders, de-risking capital, and keeping teams focused on measurable delivery.

From circular building materials to post-disaster recovery and ESG-aligned financing, Jennifer’s work spans sectors including healthcare, hospitality, data centers, and residential real estate. She has led over $500M in executed projects and structured solutions that integrate innovation, resiliency, and social impact at scale. Her leadership ensures that nothing is siloed, every detail is owned, and execution is uncompromising.

Jennifer's global network spans advanced materials, AI, and sustainable infrastructure. She doesn’t just connect the dots—she orchestrates the entire system. Under her leadership, WerkWell delivers on what others only promise: real infrastructure, real capital deployment, and real-world outcomes.

Core Competencies:

- Systems-Based Design, Development & Governance
- Circular Economy & Next-Gen Building Technologies
- ESG Infrastructure Strategy & Capital Structuring
- High-Performance Project Delivery Across Sectors
- Stakeholder Alignment & Executional Leadership

Featured

Post
Post
I turned 47 yesterday and spent most of the day thinking about the legacy I want to leave. 

An afternoon rendezvous with a dear friend, a fellow high achiever, reminded me to be a human being and not a human doing. As I gave this further thought throughout the day, I realized my achievements don't matter. It won't matter how many books I write, how many awards I receive, or how many successful exits I have. The only thing that matters is if I made a positive impact on people, on the world and, most importantly, my children. 

For the last couple years, I have been deeply driven by a bigger purpose. A desire to help people. A desire to make the world a better place - more equal, more just, more open, more harmonious, more simple. Today, I hope that when my children celebrate their 47th birthdays that I leave them a planet to celebrate on that is in better shape than it is today.

As I track what is happening between natural disasters, mass shootings, environmental disasters, wars, and the climate crisis (which is now highly politicized as fossil fuels vs. sustainability, meat vs. plant-based, us vs. them), it only makes me more motivated to deliver real solutions to our real problems. 

I transitioned from high-end residential construction building luxury homes to launching a company that makes the whole construction process more efficient, less risky and more pleasant. Over the last year, I fully revived a plan I wrote 13 years ago for a sustainable community and my mission evolved to not just changing how we build, but changing how we LIVE.

Today, I am on a mission to make existing buildings more efficient, healthy and sustainable, developing a global network of regenerative communities, and preparing to print my book. All to create a healthier balance between nature, home and people. To be more connected. To shift from achieving to being. To shift from fighting to loving - from struggling to thriving.

That is the legacy I hope to leave.

2d • Edited • 
 
2 days ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
Exactly. We have the solutions. We just need to start using them and change legislation. We have water harvesting and filtration systems that can manage massive volumes of water, and when part of a well-designed lanscape plan can reduce potable water usage up to 100% by re-using rainwater and graywater.

BUT - in most jurisdictions around the globe we can only use that water for irrigation and fire suppression. In some locations it can be re-used for toilets and sinks. Yet, the water coming out of our systems tests cleaner than the world's best drinking water. If we want to save our planet - it all starts with being smarter on how we use our most valuable resource. Without it there is no life. (and for those who don't believe we are in a planetary crisis - also no data centers)

This is not that complicated. We just have outdated systems and laws.

Founder Biotonomy.com | Co-Founder Circularliving.ai | Engineer & Architect | Advancing Nature Based, Self-Sufficient Buildings | Awarded by the United Nations, Government of Spain, Málaga City, Forbes
Founder Biotonomy.com | Co-Founder Circularliving.ai | Engineer & Architect | Advancing Nature Based, Self-Sufficient Buildings | Awarded by the United Nations, Government of Spain, Málaga City, Forbes
This is one of the biggest design mistakes cities ever made.

In most cities, rainwater and sewage go through the same pipes.

When it rains, clean water from roofs and streets mixes with dirty water from toilets and sinks.

The system can’t handle it — so to stop flooding, it dumps everything straight into rivers and the sea.

This is called a Combined Sewer Overflow —
and it happens tens of thousands of times every year across Europe,
with over 650,000 overflow points still active today.

That means billions of liters of dirty water are released every time it rains heavily.

Some newer cities tried to fix this by separating the pipes.
But instead of mixing, they now throw the rainwater away — sending it straight to the sea.

Once rainwater reaches the ocean, it becomes saltwater.
It can’t be used again for drinking, farming, or nature —
it’s lost from the freshwater cycle.

That’s why cities flood in winter and dry up in summer —
because rain never reaches the ground to refill the soil and groundwater.

Both systems fail:
◾ One pollutes water.
◾ The other wastes it.

The solution is simple:
Let rain soak into the ground.
Store it. Reuse it. Don’t throw it away.

That’s how we restore the natural water cycle —
and fix one of the biggest urban design mistakes ever made.

👉 Want to learn how to design buildings that restore water cycles?
Comment Academy, and I’ll invite you to our waiting list.

BIOTONOMY - Nature Based Architecture

We are all charged up about Critical Infrastructure, and our growing list of projects indicates the market is too. 

Why we love it? 

We get to connect different solutions and minds to build smarter, more resilient systems for the future - finding ways to better use our limited resources while creating a positive impact. 

We often talk about sustainability, but the real change happens when how we build, power, and sustain our communities work in harmony to reduce demand and eliminate (or use) waste. 

So where is innovation making a real impact now? 

→ Energy - Solar is just the beginning. 
By integrating battery storage with renewable generation like wind and solar, we can turn building sites into mini power plants - generating, storing, and using energy locally. 

→ Geothermal - In Northern Europe, geothermal fields have been used for decades, and now they are proving their impact around the world. With heating and cooling among the most energy-intensive needs we have, geothermal systems can cut that demand by up to 80%. 

→ Water - Our planet’s most valuable resource. 
We bring innovative Dutch startups into projects of all sizes to harvest, process, store and reuse rainwater and recycle greywater. In drought-stricken regions like California, capturing and reusing rainwater instead of releasing it into the ocean will transform irrigation and fire prevention, saving millions of gallons of valuable potable drinking water.

Critical infrastructure is evolving quickly - and it’s exciting to see what’s possible when innovation meets intention. 

Which of these technologies do you think will have the biggest impact in the next decade?

WerkWell provides construction management and sustainability solutions to clients ranging from high-end residential, multi-family, commercial, hospitality, and healthcare for retrofit and new construction projects. We are most impactful when engaged in the earliest stages of the project concept so we can fully align design, sustainability and budget objectives around a clear project plan that streamlines the project and delivers on average 30% cost reduction from the typical project approach. For larger projects, we facilitate design, engineering, construction and operation of next generation infrastructure with financing solutions to make sustainability make sense.

Our global team and extensive network of partners enable us to deliver projects around the world, and ensure that the right teams are connected to the right projects and clients. Together, our mission is to deliver successful projects, though our passion is to lead groundbreaking projects that have positive impact through energy reduction, cost savings and emissions reductions.

Experts in Construction. Passionate about Sustainability.
